contentrichtext.text: {{For|the Tibetan spiritual biographies|Namtar (biography)}} {{For|the village in Nepal|Namtar, Nepal}} {{Mesopotamian myth|expanded=5}} '''Namtar''' (or '''Namtaru''', or '''Namtara'''; meaning destiny or fate), was a hellish minor [[deity]] in [[Mesopotamian mythology]], god of death, and minister and messenger of [[An (mythology)|An]], [[Ereshkigal]], and [[Nergal]].<ref>Gods, Demons and Symbols of Ancient Mesopotamia: An Illustrated Dictionary By Jeremy A. Black, Anthony Green, p 134</ref><ref>http://www.encyclo.co.uk/define/Namtar</ref> Namtar was the son of [[Enlil]] and [[Ereshkigal]]; he was born before his father raped the goddess [[Ninlil]]. Namtar was considered responsible for diseases and pests. It was said that he commanded sixty diseases in the form of demons that could penetrate different parts of the human body; offerings to him were made to prevent those illnesses. It is thought that the Assyrians and Babylonians took this belief from the Sumerians after conquering them. To some they were the spirit of [[destiny|fate]], and therefore of great importance. Apparently they executed the instructions given him concerning the fate of men, and could also have power over certain of the gods. In other writings they were regarded as the personification of death, much like the modern concept of the [[Grim Reaper]].<ref>Mesopotamian religion and Ereshkigal under Encyclopædia Britannica</ref><ref>The Doctrine of Sin in the Babylonian Religion By Julian Morgenstern, Paul Tice p 18-19.</ref><ref>Myths of Babylonia and Assyria By Donald A. Mackenzie p.178</ref> In the story of Ishtar's Descent to earth, acting as [[Ereshkigal]]'s 'messenger', Namtar curses [[Ishtar]] with 60 diseases, naming five of the head, feet, side, eyes, and heart, after she arrives to earth.<ref>An Encyclopaedia of Religions by Maurice Arthur Canney p. 258</ref> Namtar was regarded as the beloved son of Bêl/Enlil, and was married to the underworld goddess [[Hušbišag]]. == References == Michael Jordan, Encyclopedia of Gods, Kyle Cathie Limited, 2002 Descent of the Goddess Ishtar into the Lower World, http://www.ancienttexts.org/library/mesopotamian/ishtar.html {{Reflist}} [[Category:Mesopotamian deities]] [[Category:Health gods]] [[Category:Death gods]] {{myth-stub}}
